data.title: Spy them all
data.statement:
You sent a <<confidential>> email to all of your employees. 
This email must remains for internal use only.

So, you set a <<unique marker>> on the email for each employees.
Like this, if someone share his email with a journalist, you <<can>> retrieve his identity.

The <<unique marker>> is a <<unique unsigned integer>> [[id]] encoded inside spaces between words.
If you have {{1}} space between 2 words, it's considered as a bit {{0}}
If you have {{2}} spaces between 2 words, it's considered as a bit {{1}}

Bits order use a <<big endian>> representation (smallest bit at the end).
[[id]] are encoded <<only>> with required bits for storing <<any>> possible values.

As <<example>>, for [[N]]  = {{14}} employees, we have:
⇨ [[Id]] range is  [ {{0}} ~ {{13}} ]
⇨ Binary representation of {{13}} is {{1101}}
⇨ In this case {{4}} bits will be used for encoding/decoding the <<unique marker>>
⇨ [[Id]] {{7}} will be encoded {{0111}}

Email have at least the number of spaces required but  can have more than required.
Extra spaces are not significants for decoding the [[id]].

You see the contents of an email on <<Internet>> and you have to find the <<employee to fire>> !

testCases.title: 2 bits
testCases.testIn:
3
Leon
Marc
Jean
Lorem  ipsum dolor  sit  amet.

data.stubGenerator:
read N:int
loop N read EMPLOYEE:string(512)
read EMAIL:string(2048)
write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1>> : An integer [[N]] giving the number of employees. 
<<[[N]] next lines>> : The employee's name. His [[id]] is his position in this list (starting at {{0}})
<<Last Line>> : The email contents with a <<unique marker>> identifying an employee.
data.outputDescription: <<Line 1 :>> Name of the employee to fire

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You sent a confidential email to all of your employees.
This email must remains for internal use only.

So, you set a unique marker on the email for each employees.
Like this, if someone share his email with a journalist, you can retrieve his identity.

The unique marker is a unique unsigned integer id encoded inside spaces between words.
If you have 1 space between 2 words, it's considered as a bit 0
If you have 2 spaces between 2 words, it's considered as a bit 1

Bits order use a big endian representation (smallest bit at the end).
id are encoded only with required bits for storing any possible values.

As example, for N = 14 employees, we have:
⇨ Id range is [ 0 ~ 13 ]
⇨ Binary representation of 13 is 1101
⇨ In this case 4 bits will be used for encoding/decoding the unique marker
⇨ Id 7 will be encoded 0111

Email have at least the number of spaces required but can have more than required.
Extra spaces are not significants for decoding the id.

You see the contents of an email on Internet and you have to find the employee to fire !
Input
Line 1 : An integer N giving the number of employees.
N next lines : The employee's name. His id is his position in this list (starting at 0)
Last Line : The email contents with a unique marker identifying an employee.
Output
Line 1 : Name of the employee to fire
Constraints
1 <= N <= 255
Example
Input
3
Leon
Marc
Jean
Lorem  ipsum dolor  sit  amet.
Output
Jean
